{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-215-06-A |Item_parent=Purpuras in adults and children |Item_parent_short=Purpuras in adults and children |Rank=A |Title=Know how to prescribe emergency laboratory tests for purpura |Description=None |Topic=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=6}} ==''In case of thrombocytopenic purpura'''== - Blood count (in the case of purpura, there is no need to check for thrombocytopenia (platelet abnormality) on a citrate tube, as there are clinical signs associated with thrombocytopenia); - Search for a ''decrease in the prothrombin rate (PT)'', or a ''prolongation of the activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)'', fibrinogen (in search of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)); - '''Blood smear ([[Prescription and analysis of blood smear SD-222|prescription and analysis of blood smear]]);''' - Liver function tests ; - Blood group, test for irregular agglutinins (which will enable a platelet or red blood cell transfusion to be carried out if necessary).
==In case of fever == In case of '''fever ([[Hyperthermia/fever SD-044|hyperthermia/fever]]) and/or new heart murmur ([[Discovery of abnormalities on cardiac auscultation SD-018|discovery of abnormalities on cardiac auscultation]])''': '''prescription of blood cultures ([[Positive blood culture SD-190|positive blood culture]]).'''
==In case of '''vascular purpura'''== - '''C-reactive protein (CRP) ([[c-reactive protein (cr) elevation SD-203|C-reactive protein (CRP) elevation])''''' - Blood count, blood ionogram, creatinine - '''[[Proteinuria SD-212|Proteinuria]]''''

question.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate emergency laboratory test to prescribe for a patient presenting with thrombocytopenic purpura?
question.option_a: Blood count on a citrate tube to check for thrombocytopenia
question.option_b: Measurement of prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
